title: Quiz 4: The Lower Limb
description: Comprehensive assessment of lower limb anatomy, including the gluteal region, thigh compartments, knee joint mechanics, and neurovasculature of the leg and foot.

questions.question: Arrange the contents of the Femoral Triangle from Lateral to Medial:
questions.explanation: NAVY (Lateral to Medial): Nerve, Artery, Vein, Y-fronts (Canal/Lymphatics). Note: The Femoral Nerve is outside the femoral sheath.
questions.hint: Use the mnemonic NAVY.

questions.question: Which muscle is responsible for 'unlocking' the knee joint at the beginning of flexion?
questions.explanation: The Popliteus muscle laterally rotates the femur on the tibia (or medially rotates the tibia on the femur) to unlock the knee from full extension.
questions.hint: It is a small triangular muscle behind the knee.

questions.question: Match the thigh compartment with its primary nerve supply:
questions.explanation: Anterior = Femoral. Medial = Obturator. Posterior = Sciatic (mostly Tibial component, except short head of biceps).
questions.hint: Think about the function: Kick (Femoral), Squeeze (Obturator), Run (Sciatic).

questions.question: Which of the following structures pass BEHIND the medial malleolus? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Tom, Dick, And Very Nervous Harry: Tibialis posterior, Flexor Digitorum longus, Artery (Post Tibial), Vein, Nerve (Tibial), Hallucis longus. Tibialis Anterior is in front of the ankle.
questions.hint: Remember 'Tom, Dick, And Very Nervous Harry'.

questions.question: A patient presents with 'foot drop'. Which nerve is most likely damaged?
questions.explanation: The Common Peroneal nerve winds around the neck of the fibula. Damage here paralyzes the anterior compartment (dorsiflexors), leading to foot drop.
questions.hint: It is vulnerable at the fibular neck.

questions.question: The Great Saphenous Vein passes ___BLANK___ to the medial malleolus and drains into the ___BLANK___ vein at the saphenous opening.
questions.explanation: The Great Saphenous Vein runs ANTERIOR to the medial malleolus (a key site for venous cut-down) and drains into the Femoral vein.
questions.hint: Position at the ankle is critical for cannulation.

questions.question: The lateral meniscus of the knee is C-shaped and firmly attached to the collateral ligament.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The MEDIAL meniscus is C-shaped and attached to the medial collateral ligament (prone to injury). The LATERAL meniscus is O-shaped and more mobile/loosely attached.
questions.hint: Medial is less Mobile (and C-shaped).

questions.question: Review the table below. Which row correctly identifies the action of Gluteus Medius and Minimus?

richContent.content:
Muscle GroupPrimary ActionFunction in Walking
AExtensionPropulsion
BAbductionPrevents pelvic tilt
CAdductionStabilizes knee

questions.explanation: Gluteus Medius and Minimus are abductors. Their crucial function is to stabilize the pelvis when the opposite leg is raised during walking. Failure results in Trendelenburg gait.
questions.hint: They keep the pelvis level.

questions.question: What is the safest site for an intragluteal injection to avoid sciatic nerve injury?
questions.explanation: The upper outer quadrant of the buttock is safe. The sciatic nerve runs through the lower and medial aspects.
questions.hint: Think about the quadrant furthest from the nerve's path.

questions.question: Which of the following are intracapsular structures of the knee joint? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The cruciate ligaments and the tendon of popliteus are intracapsular (but extrasynovial). The collateral ligaments and patellar ligament are extracapsular.
questions.hint: Which structures are deep inside the joint space?

questions.question: The dorsalis pedis artery is a continuation of which artery?
questions.explanation: The anterior tibial artery passes under the extensor retinaculum to become the dorsalis pedis artery on the dorsum of the foot.
questions.hint: The artery on the front of the leg continues onto the front of the foot.

questions.question: Match the ligament/structure with its function in maintaining foot arches:
questions.explanation: Spring ligament (calcaneonavicular) is the key support for the medial longitudinal arch. Long plantar supports the lateral arch. Peroneus longus and Tibialis Posterior form a stirrup for the transverse arch.
questions.hint: Spring is for the high arch (Medial).

questions.question: Trace the arterial blood supply from the pelvis to the foot:
questions.explanation: External Iliac -> Femoral (at inguinal lig) -> Popliteal (at adductor hiatus) -> Posterior Tibial -> Plantar arteries.
questions.hint: Follow the main axis down the leg.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the 'Unhappy Triad' of knee injuries?

options.text: ACL, Medial Collateral Ligament, Medial Meniscus
PCL, Lateral Collateral Ligament, Lateral Meniscus

questions.explanation: The Unhappy Triad (O'Donoghue's triad) typically involves the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL), Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL), and Medial Meniscus. It occurs when the knee is hit from the outside while the foot is planted.
questions.hint: It involves the medial side and the anterior cross.

questions.question: The sciatic nerve divides into the ___BLANK___ nerve and the ___BLANK___ nerve at the apex of the popliteal fossa.
questions.explanation: The sciatic nerve divides into the Tibial and Common Peroneal nerves usually just above the popliteal fossa.
questions.hint: One goes straight down, the other winds laterally.

questions.question: A fracture of the femoral neck is more likely to cause avascular necrosis of the femoral head than an intertrochanteric fracture.
questions.explanation: TRUE. Intracapsular (neck) fractures disrupt the retinacular arteries supplying the head. Extracapsular (intertrochanteric) fractures usually spare the blood supply.
questions.hint: Think about where the blood supply enters the head.

questions.question: Which structures are found in the Adductor (Hunter's) Canal? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Adductor canal contains the Femoral Artery, Femoral Vein, Saphenous Nerve, and Nerve to Vastus Medialis. The Femoral nerve itself divides earlier. Profunda is deeper.
questions.hint: The main vessels plus a cutaneous nerve.

questions.question: What is the name of the deep fascia of the thigh?
questions.explanation: The deep fascia of the thigh is the Fascia Lata. It thickens laterally to form the Iliotibial Tract.
questions.hint: It means 'broad band'.

questions.question: Which specific bursa is inflamed in 'Housemaid's Knee'?
questions.explanation: Prepatellar bursitis ('Housemaid's Knee') is caused by friction between the skin and the patella, often from kneeling.
questions.hint: It is in front of the kneecap.

questions.question: Match the muscle with its insertion point:
questions.explanation: Quads -> Tibial Tuberosity. Biceps -> Fibula. Iliopsoas -> Lesser Trochanter. Gluteus Medius -> Greater Trochanter.
questions.hint: Where does the muscle pull to move the bone?

questions.question: Which nerve provides cutaneous sensation to the medial aspect of the leg and foot?
questions.explanation: The Saphenous nerve (branch of Femoral) supplies the medial side. Sural supplies lateral/posterior. Superficial Peroneal supplies the dorsum. Deep Peroneal supplies the 1st web space.
questions.hint: It runs with the Great Saphenous Vein.

questions.question: Which structure prevents anterior displacement of the tibia on the femur?
questions.explanation: The Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) prevents Anterior displacement of the tibia. The PCL prevents Posterior displacement.
questions.hint: ACL = Anterior.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles are Lateral Rotators of the hip? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Piriformis, Obturators, Gemelli, and Quadratus Femoris are lateral rotators. Gluteus Minimus and TFL are medial rotators.
questions.hint: The small muscles deep in the buttock.

questions.question: The femoral canal is located lateral to the femoral vein.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The femoral canal (containing lymphatics) is MEDIAL to the femoral vein. Arrangement (Lat -> Med): Nerve, Artery, Vein, Canal.
questions.hint: Remember NAVY. Y (Canal) is most medial.

questions.question: In 'Compartment Syndrome' of the leg, which procedure is performed to relieve pressure?
questions.explanation: Fasciotomy involves cutting the deep fascia to release the pressure built up within the muscle compartments.
questions.hint: Cutting the fascia.
